content.body: Yeah, I was. I don't care too much about getting rid of the normal PI variant, I don't think that allows for much simplification of the model. At least not as long as everyone does XSLT.
Alan Stearns: heya, we revised the proposal for trivial changes to take into account the point you mentioned: https://github.com/whatwg/sg/issues/63#issuecomment-1387475350

content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> Yeah, I was. I don't care too much about getting rid of the normal PI variant, I don't think that allows for much simplification of the model. At least not as long as everyone does XSLT.

The normal variant is just such a large piece of the platform to have around with zero spec. (Does it affect document.styleSheets? Load event timing? Render blocking? Whoooo knowssss)
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
Yeah, I was. I don't care too much about getting rid of the normal PI variant, I don't think that allows for much simplification of the model. At least not as long as everyone does XSLT.

content.formatted_body: Domenic: thanks to you I think I found a bug in https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#scheme-state

content.body: Domenic: there's no EOF handling for the state override case
content.formatted_body: Domenic: there's no EOF handling for the state override case

content.body: Hmm... it would just validation error, return failure in that case right?
Which is probably correct for `location.protocol = ""`?
Domenic: well, how does the input "blah" terminate currently?
content.formatted_body: Domenic: well, how does the input "blah" terminate currently?

content.body: I think the input always ends with a colon?
No, we have tests that expect the opposite and implementations don't require that
location.protocol input does
Because the setter always appends ":"
before hitting the parser
Looks like URL's protocol setter does too
Aaah, thanks!
Karl: hey, I'm looking at IdnaTestV2.txt and I was wondering if you could help me out
content.formatted_body: Karl: hey, I'm looking at IdnaTestV2.txt and I was wondering if you could help me out

content.body: Karl: in particular I'm not sure I understand how `xn--0.pt` relates to _VerifyDnsLength_
content.formatted_body: Karl: in particular I'm not sure I understand how xn--0.pt relates to VerifyDnsLength

content.body: Karl: it seems that when you don't enforce _VerifyDnsLength_ that should just stay as-is, but browsers reject it instead
content.formatted_body: Karl: it seems that when you don't enforce VerifyDnsLength that should just stay as-is, but browsers reject it instead
